rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Marzuola is not only a great person, but a great teacher too. Though his class was very difficult, he curves a lot and has become one of my favorite teachers at Chapel Hill. Do not be scared by a low test grade with him, because he will curve your final grade up and he will always be there to help you. Take this teacher.

Marzuola is great! Yeah, his tests are hard, but he curves them, so even if you get a 52 (like I did) he'll round it up to a B if you're close enough to the average. Homework was VERY long, took more than 10 hours a week to complete. He's a very good lecturer and has lots of times for office hours, so you can (and should) get extra help if needed.
He seems to have a solid understanding of what he teaches, but is not exactly proficient at communicating ideas easily for students who are learning the difficult concepts for the first time.

Jeremy seems like a very very good teacher. For higher level maths. I think his niche just resides in graduate level classes, not differential equations. He is super into what he teaches, but he gets almost too into topics that make some things confusing. I'd look forward to taking him in a higher math class though.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Professor Camassa is my favorite professor! He presents the material to make it interesting, & class is usually very entertaining. Exams are pretty fair.

This professor is terrible. He's difficult to understand as well as extremely unorganized. The class didn't follow the syllabus at all. He is rude and constantly interrupts his students to correct them on objective and irrelevant details. If you have a class with him, get out while you still can. He is the worst professor I've ever had.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Hans is a nice guy but his lectures are confusing and unhelpful. Tests are not very hard but they are graded very harshly and arbitrarily. You have to teach yourself a lot.

If you can take Math 383 with Hans, do it, he is a gem in the math department. He actually explains difficult concepts at a comprehensible level and understands that the class realistically may not remember every concept from previous calc classes. Not much homework and test are VERY straightforward, no trick questions. Very helpful at office hours

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Dr. Miller is a wonderful professor! She really cares about students and is very helpful if you go to her office hours.  She ends class early for homework questions and gives concise answers to questions. Tests are easy - definitely do the practice tests, and she allows a 1-page formula sheet. I definitely recommend her class.
Dr. Miller is an awesome prof!

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Professor Griffith definitely is very intelligent. He isn't too interactive with his students and is a little unclear when it comes to assignments. The homework is helpful, but takes a long time to complete.  Definitely a difficult class, but overall Prof Griffith was a fine teacher.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: He is the best option for a difficult math class. You won't find any surprise on his tests as long as you go to class.
He gives awesome lectures and very easy tests. The workload is average. It's helpful to review MATH383 before you take this class.
By far the best math teacher I've ever had. As long as you go to lectures and pay attention, his tests are easy to study for and to pass
Taylor is an awesome professor!  He is approachable and very easy to talk to. The tests are very easy as long as you do the homework.

I really enjoyed this class. 521 is a very hard course in general but his teaching makes it much easier. His exams are very fair. If you review the homework before the exam you should be fine. Dr. Taylor is also very helpful and really approachable to ask questions. Strongly recommend!

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: She is an okay lecturer. She loses her thought process and can ramble, leaving students confused as to what to write down. Her mid terms were not very hard but if you accidentally make a mistake, you'll regret it because there is very little partial credit. Her final was extremely hard.

How does she even have this high of a rating? She does not give partial credit (which is ridiculous for a math class) and is very opposed to answering any questions about tests. You can do poorly in this class even if you understand the material.  She also grades attendance and doesn't really tell you that until the end of class...

Hawkins is a very good and clear lecturer. She's very helpful if you ask her questions in class. I really liked that about her.  HOWEVER, she's a hard grader! Her tests are easy, but if you make one, silly mistake, she gives almost no partial credit (if at all!). So for a test with only five questions, it's very easy to do very poorly.

Jane Hawkins and extremely rude and gets mad when students ask simple questions. She takes off full points for simple algebra mistakes and doesn't care about her 383 students. I could not recommend this professor to anyone.
Really cares about the class and making sure we understand the material. That said, you need to put effort into it on your own time, otherwise there's no way you'll be prepared. Lecture was helpful.

Terrible teacher. She is knowledgeable about the material but has trouble explaining it. You have to teach yourself. Exams are very hard and she grades harshly. She is a nice person but I still recommend taking MATH 521 with someone else.
Great teacher! This course is very challenging but her tests are pretty fair.

Honestly, I love this professor. Her class is no where close to easy but is upper level math so it is expected to be difficult. If you go to her office hours, she is extremely helpful and does everything she can to help you understand. Shes' hard to catch outside of office hours but she will try to be flexible. Tests are fair and similar to hw.
Good teacher. She teaches hard classes so some may not like her because of that.  She is not easy, but is fair if you work hard.

Quite scatter-brained -- was probably thinking about her research instead of the class.  Very smart woman, but not the best teacher -- ended up making many mistakes on board, but she knew what she was doing.  Tests weren't too bad.  If you study & do hw, you'll do fine.  Math center can be helpful.
No Comments
she is not too hard, but she is difficult to catch outside of class for questions...does not answer email
No Comments

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Very difficult class, need to put in lots of work. Textbook (Bretscher) was useless so you'll probably need to refer to other textssources. His lectures weren't helpfulengaging, I basically self-studied this class. Gives large amounts of HW especially during weeks of tests. First test was easy but the second test and final were much, much harder.

I'm only a freshman, but by far the hardest class I've ever taken. I thought I was good at math, then I took this class. By the end of the semester it mostly makes sense, but during it I was never more lost.

This is one of the best teachers I have had, going out of his way to help you individually if he knows you're trying hard. He is NOT the right teacher for everyone. Be prepared to exhaust the material before class, in order to benefit from his brilliance. He can teach very fast, but will slow down and explain things clearly if you ask him to.

I have had Professor Kumar before for Math 233. There is no doubt, his tests are very stressful. However, he spends a great amount of time making sure students know each section very well and is always helpful when students have questions. He asks questions in class, so if students don't understand, he will notice and help correct this.

Very nice professor.  His accent is difficult to understand at first, but you'll get the hang of it.  The quiz questions come directly from the homework, but the tests are what killed my grade in this class.  He throws a bunch of curve balls at you.  This ended up being my lowest grade at UNC.

He was a very nice man, but he was not clear at all. His tests were extremely difficult. There was no room for mistakes. Unless you are a math whiz, I would not suggest taking him, because you will recieve insufficient help.
No Comments
No Comments

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: I took calc in high school, and still had to study a lot for this class. However, if you do study thoroughly for each test, it's possible to do well. Definitely go to class. Also, he curves your grades at the end of the semester, so don't completely freak out. I thought I would end up with a B or B-, but ended up getting an A-.

I had very little exposure to calc before taking this course, but had considered myself good at math, and I struggled quite a bit. He would barely touch the surface of a topic in lecture, and then the homework would feel impossible. He assigns quite a bit of homework. Tests were pretty tricky, just because partial credit was rare.

Dr. Jones explained the concepts well and I found his pace to be appropriate. He's a fairly funny guy too. (Not funny in the normal sense, but like professor funny). Take notes, pay attention, don't make dumb mistakes on the exams, and you should be good.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: He was a very kind teacher. He lectures straight from the book. He wasn't a very good lecturer, but he was very active in office hours.  Office hours weren't the most helpful (due to the fact a lot of people came, and it was hard to get individual attention). His tests are fair and the homework is reasonable in length and difficulty.
I liked this class a lot.  I thought it was pretty easy and the homework was actually based on what he did in class, which I thought he explained well.

This was not a hard class, but when I didn't understand concepts, he couldn't (or wouldn't) explain things in a different way so that I might understand, he just repeated himself.  NOT HELPFUL.  English wasn't first language, took awhile to get a hang of his accent.  Lectures tended to be abstract, and difficult to follow (and I'm a math major).  It's a requirement for my major, if it's not for yours...don't take it.  And if you can avoid it...don't take him.
No Comments
No Comments
EXTREMELY good teacher and very fair

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Pretty fun class, Mucha's lectures were very well organized and he taught intelligently but not pedantically. He was very available for office hours and help if needed. Good sense of humor and ability to keep the class light while never completely going off on tangents. I would recommend the class; the subject matter is difficult but Mucha is good.

Very enthusiastic and helpful. The class (MATH233) was rather difficult but Mucha was very willing to help on an individual level despite 50+ in the class. Lectures focus more on solving problems rather than deriving equations. I enjoyed this but it might work less for some.

PLEASE I repeat PLEASE do not take this class. I took this class on the premise that it would be told based on biological principles instead of     the usual physics based calculus. He did this for about a week then he just started teaching some foreign language. Half of the class was lost and his lectures are very unorganized. On a positive if you

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Really easy online tests with lots of attempts.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Comprehension is an issue (accent + flies through content), very cordial. Material is tough but the bi-weekly homework is manageable, Final (50% of grade) is take-home w/ a bonus question. Final research group project (30% of grade) takes a bit of work but will boost your grade. Doesn't take attendance, but skipping class means missing material

His accent takes a bit of getting used to, and he tends to fly past materials if nobody stops him. He is very passionate about his subject and will not stop to clarify if nobody asks him to. The final is a take home test

Couldn't even understand what he was teaching, so I never really learned the material. However, he goes over what will be on each test exactly, and test/hw aren't too difficult. Get someone else though if you want to learn

Ivan is very hard to understand, but he is very friendly. he can be very helpful if you know how to ask the right questions. I have seen him give answers to exams during the exam time. he also makes it almost impossible to fail the course: many tries on h, 2 tries on exam questions, and the process for how to solve exam question before the exam.

Ivan is a very kind person, and he genuinely wants you to understand the material, but he won't force you to. I had Calc 3 (multi var), and the day before each exam, he showed you an example of each problem on the test as well as exactly how to find the answer. I haven't learned anything from him this year but will ace the final grade easily.
Ivan is a sweet Russian guy who loves Rabbits, History, Sweaters and Ivan's Game.  His endearing personality makes combinatorics a memorable class.

His accent is very thick and normally difficult to understand. He speaks through sayings and odd stories, which sometimes helps but sometimes just compounds the difficulty. I am good at math (scored an 800 on the math SAT), yet this class kicked my butt because I couldn't understand him and therefore couldn't understand the material.
Had him for FYS Combinatorics.  The class wasn't hard but his accent takes some getting used to.  He knows what he's talking about but sometimes it's hard for him to make you understand.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Professor Metcalfe is definitely the best professor I have ever had. Amazing lectures. I learned so much. Math 521 is hard, but take it with Jason. It won't be easy, but it will be so rewarding, and you will not regret it. He is a wonderful person and cares so much about his students. He always goes above and beyond. Absolutely exceptional.

THE BEST professor I have ever had. Jason Metcalfe is both an amazing mathematician and an amazing professor. His class was not easy, but it was so rewarding. If Jason Metcalfe is teaching a course- take it. Regardless of what it is. I would take any course with him, even if I didn't need it for my major. He is awesome!!!

I can't recommend Jason highly enough. He by far the best math professor I've had at UNC. His class is hard but worth it especially if you are considering math grad school. His number one priority is making sure his students learn. He is always willing to give advice on math, grad school, or anything else you may need. Very accommodating.

Jason is the best professor I've ever had!!! MATH 521 is notoriously difficult, but prof Metcalfe makes the material attainable. He cares a lot about his students and will spend the entire lecture on one proof if you are confused. Not the easiest prof, but you will definitely learn the material well. I wish I could take him for all my math classes.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Honestly,  I love this man. He saved me in calculus. Whenever I needed help, he was there. His lectures are long and tend to put you to sleep, but if you can stay awake through them, you'll understand how thorough and well put together they are.

Sawon is brilliant and helpful, very clear but class moves quickly so pay attention. also, do the effing homework - annoying but worth it! class is longest ever but passable without always attending lecture. overall good professor - and an aussie! ;D

Sawon was not a difficult teacher, easy B if you pay attention in class and easy A if you have taken calculus before. (You will still need to pay attention in class). Attendance is basically optional, so it is harder to pay attention in class than it sounds.

Sawon is clear throughout lectures and always asks if anyone has questions. He does a great job at explaining concepts and taking his time. Homework is online, which is really annoying, but it is doable. The tests get progressively harder but are also doable. Dont really need the textbook, just the webassign code.

Quiet, mild-mannered, math-magician. Intelligent, but a really nice guy if you get to know him well enough. Go to class, and try to stay awake. If you have trouble with web-assign, speak up in a recitation. Sawon loves to help, often with a quiet joke a soft smirk. A mystery, worth getting to know better.

You don't have to show up to class which is nice. 2 tests are fair, one sucks for the midterms. Trust me, you don't need to understand the Web Assigns. Just do them by whatever means necessary and don't take them lightly. This curve needs to be huge though, I'm anxiously waiting to see how nice it is.

Very clear in his examples, willing to answer questions, and discuss any problems during office hours. He assigns homework based on the material covered during class, and every now and then will throw a curveball. He uses webassign, which isn't the most user-friendly website, but the problems are relevant to the test. He has an Australian accent.
Sawon is very clear in his examples, and will answer any questions.  Also, he is very helpful in office hours.  He also has a British accent.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Mitran definitely knows the material very well.  He expects you to be more than proficient with understanding and be very active in reading ahead.  Be ready to program a lot. I worked extremely hard to finish the hw, but those are the majority of your grade.  He can be blunt and condescending and but not necessarily unwarranted.  Text is useful

Prof. Mitran is a very interesting professor, but his lectures are long and sometimes don't cover what you need to know on the homework assignments. Tests are difficult and he doesn't really review for them at all.

Lectures are long, but you have to pay attention or else you will fall behind. Each homework takes about 8 hours so start much earlier. He uses half-functioning virtual machine called Tarheel Linux that you might have to ask ITS to help you install. He uses Octave too. The tests are easy but you have to know the concepts and steps.
Soooo many homework ,  long lecture, better learn those material by yourself
Best professor I have ever had in the math department. He holds high expectations for his students, but his tests are very fair and he is also a fair grader.

Dr. Mitran is undoubtedly a very intelligent individual. However, he fails to clearly communicate many of the ideas he wishes to teach in class, and I learned more reading outside papers on the topics discussed than I did from his lectures or notes. He is also an incredible tough grader and can be very derisive towards questions he feels are inane.

The course is demanding, and he has no interest in holding your hand. He often belittled those who asked questions in class, creating an environment where everyone was afraid to speak up.  Not a nice guy.  That said, he lectures well.  I learned a lot in this class, but I wasn't a rewarding experience.

Mitran's MATH 566 was the most difficult mathematics class of my undergraduate career (BS Math).  Having survived the class though, I can honestly say I learned more from it than from any other.  Mitran is a strict and intimidating professor, but I feel this is a fair trade for the amount of knowledge he tends to impart.
Prof. Mitran will push you and make things difficult, but he's fair and you get a ton out of the class. Highly recommended!!!11!
Lectures were interesting and well motivated. By far the best lecturer I have had. The workload is hard but fair and helpful to learning the material.
Honestly this is by far the worst professor I have ever had
No Comments
No Comments
